A sound in the sky says the king sees what he sees.
He then gave it to him with a [tuft of *hair].
The next sitting bodhisattva was called 'having attained the highest vow.'

source_sentence: 王復持是[疊*毛]欲奉上之。
translation: The king then took this [pile of *hair] and wanted to present it to him.
He said, "Attain the higher vow.
"He who seeks to be freed from nirvāṇa.
'I won't accept anything from this.
Nor will I accept what belongs to ordinary people.
Why is that?
An ordinary person.
It's called having worldly affairs and not accepting them.

source_sentence: 亦不從求羅漢辟支佛者。
translation: Nor does he receive something from someone who seeks to become a arhat or pratyekabuddha.
He receives what's given to him.
He doesn't have two minds to accept it.
Nor does he have two minds.
Therefore, it's said that what's received is more than what's liberated.
The king then wanted to put his robe on the bodhisattva.
Suddenly, it didn't appear, and he didn't know where it was.
He only heard his voice and didn't see his form.
He said.
"Give him this robe for his visible body.

source_sentence: 如是次第一一以衣與之皆悉不現。
translation: Thus, the first one in turn gives him robes, but he doesn't show up at all.

source_sentence: 乃至床机坐處悉亦不現。
translation: Even his bed, machine, and seat are all invisible.
They only hear their voice.
He says, "That person's body that's present gives it robes.

source_sentence: 乃至五百聲聞皆亦不受。
translation: Even the 500 śrāvakas wouldn't accept it.
The king was diligent in his thoughts.
'The bodhisattvas, monks, and nuns are all dead.
Who will I give my robe to?
He gave it to the very large lady of the central palace.
The lady didn't show up then either.
The king then attained samādhi.
He didn't see forms.
He doesn't see women either.
Nor did he see a man.

source_sentence: 乃至垣牆樹木室宅城郭。
translation: It didn't even see walls, trees, mansions, or cities.
There was still some remaining thought, saying.
'There's my body and all forms and consciousnesses.'
'They've all stopped.'
They also hear their voice.

source_sentence: 如一切有所見當自見疑。
translation: 'As with everything that's seen, you will see and doubt for yourself.'

source_sentence: 如所見疑見一切諸法亦復如是。
translation: Seeing what's doubted, he sees all things in the same way.
He then takes his robe and wants to put it back on himself.

source_sentence: 不見其身心(說此忘相文多不載)文殊言。
translation: He doesn't see his body or mind (a text that explains this forgetfulness is not often included), and Mañjuśrī says.

source_sentence: 曾聞佛說作逆罪者當入大泥犁不。
translation: "Have you ever heard the Buddha say that someone who commits a heinous act will go to the great hell?
The king said, "I've heard it.
'Do you yourself know that you'll go into the mire?'" the king said.
The king said.

source_sentence: 得佛有法上生天入泥犁者不。
translation: 'Will you obtain the Buddha's teaching that those who go up to heaven will enter the nirvāṇa?'

source_sentence: 有法安隱當至泥洹者不。
translation: Is there a way to be tranquil that will lead to nirvāṇa?
Mañjuśrī said no. The king said.
"I know the emptiness of all dharmas.
Why is that?

source_sentence: 泥犁上天安隱亦復皆空。
translation: Up in the niraya, up in heaven, and in well-being, they're also empty.
There's nothing corruptible about the dharmas.
That's why they enter the Dharma body.

source_sentence: 法身者亦無天上人間泥犁禽獸薜荔等。
translation: 'Dharma body' means there are no gods, humans, mud, plows, animals, ferns, or other things.

source_sentence: 世王諸逆以淨已得是忍。
translation: The king of the world has attained this kind of forbearance after purifying his adversities.
The king said.

source_sentence: 一切諸法悉淨無所沾污。
translation: "All dharmas are completely purified and unsullied.

source_sentence: 說是語時疾得信忍(出阿闍世王經下卷又出普超三昧第二第三卷)。
translation: When he spoke these words, he quickly attained the tolerance of faith (from the second roll of the King Ajātaśatru Sutra and from the second and third rolls of the Puso Samādhi).
The Great King of Radiance Begins to Awaken the Mind of Enlightenment VIII
Ānanda knew what the people were thinking.
He said to the Buddha, "Bhagavān!
"What were the causes for first arousing the attitude of enlightenment?
The Buddha said.
"In a distant past, there was a great king in Jambudvīpa.
There was a great king in Jambudvīpa.
His name was Mahāprabhāsa.
He was blessed with great intelligence.
The king of a nearby country was close to him.
He even gave each other a gift that was treasured by his country.
The king of that country then hunted down two elephants.
They were white like a pāri with seven sticks supporting the ground.
He adorned them with a variety of treasures of the highest order.
He sent someone to deliver them.
The king of light then saw the elephants and was pleased.
He sent the elephant master Sanjar.
He was commanded to send him.
He was soon trained and obeyed.
He went to the king and told him.
"The elephant has now been trained.
May the king observe and test it?
The king then assembled his ministers and ordered them to examine the elephant.
After the large crowd had gathered, the king first raised the elephant out of the city to play.
The king first raised the elephant and took it out of the city to play.
The elephant's energy was vigorous.
He saw a herd of elephants at the lotus pond.
He ran after the elephants and reached a deep forest.
The king's body then broke open and bled.
He thought to himself that he was going to die.
He fought with his hand against a branch of a tree, and the elephant left the king's residence.
He got down from the tree and sat on the ground, suffering great distress.
The elephant master bowed his head and said.
"May the king not be sad and distressed!
The elephant's lustful mind stops being disgusted with defilement.
He will thus return himself, thinking about the beautiful food and drink in the grass.
The king then told him.
"I won't use it again!
The elephant's result will be his return.
The elephant master said to the king.
"Now, the elephant will come back!
The king said.
"I don't need you, and I don't need the elephant.
The bishop then asked the king.
"If the king doesn't need it, then...
Please only observe my method of training the elephant.
The king then gave him permission.

source_sentence: 尋使師作七鐵丸燒令極赤。
translation: He had a master make seven iron balls and burn them until they were extremely red.
After he made them, he said to himself.
'The elephant will surely die if it swallows this ball.'
The king then sometimes repented and said.
"Great king!

source_sentence: 此白象寶唯轉輪王乃得之耳。
translation: 'This white elephant treasure was obtained only by the wheel-turning king.
Now, it's a minor mistake that shouldn't be lost.'
The king became angry and told him.
"Go away!
The elephant master told the elephant.
"Swallow this iron ball.

source_sentence: 若不吞者當以鐵鉤斷裂汝腦。
translation: If you don't swallow it, an iron hook will sever your brain.
The elephant knew his thoughts.
'I'd rather swallow this hot iron ball and die!'
He bent his knees and looked to the king in tears, hoping to be saved.

source_sentence: 王怒徐視散闍告象何不吞丸。
translation: The king angrily looked at him and told the elephant why he hadn't swallowed the ball.
The elephant then took the ball, put it in his mouth, and swallowed it.
It went into his belly, burned, and passed straight through, and he died.
The ball fell to the ground while still red.
Seeing this, the king regretted it.
He then told Sañjaya.
"You've trained the elephant, haven't you?
Why couldn't you have restrained it in the forest?

source_sentence: 時淨居天知光明王應發菩提心。
translation: The Jñānacitra gods then knew that King Bright should arouse the aspiration for enlightenment.
He had the elephant master kneel down and answer the king.
"I'm only able to tame the body, not the mind.
Only the Buddha can tame the mind.''
The king said.
"What kind of Buddha is that?
He's a surname birth.
He answered that there are two kinds of family-born people.
One is born of wisdom ...
The second is greatly compassionate.
He diligently practices six things.
They're called the six perfections.
After fully possessing virtue and wisdom, they're called a buddha.
He'll be called a buddha.
The king perked up when he heard that.

source_sentence: 即起洗浴更著新衣四向作禮。
translation: He got up, washed, put on new robes, and paid homage in all directions.

source_sentence: 於一切眾生起大悲心燒香立誓。
translation: He aroused great compassion for all sentient beings, burned incense, and made a vow.

source_sentence: 願我所有功德迴向佛道。
translation: 'May all my merits be directed toward the Buddha Way.

source_sentence: 自調其心亦當調伏一切眾生。
translation: Regulating my own mind, I will also regulate all sentient beings.

source_sentence: 若於地獄有所益者當入是獄。
translation: If there's any benefit in hell, I'll go to that hell.
I'll never abandon the mind of enlightenment.
After making this vow, he vowed.
The six kinds of trembling shook him.

source_sentence: 諸山大海虛空之中自然樂聲。
translation: The mountains and seas and the sky naturally make a joyful noise.
The Buddha told the monks.

source_sentence: 爾時白象吞鐵丸者難陀是也。
translation: "At the time, that white elephant swallowed an iron ball, and that was Nandha.
That elephant master at the time was Śāriputra.
The shining king is I myself.

source_sentence: 我於爾時見象調從始發道心(出賢愚經第三卷)。
translation: It was then that I saw the elephant adjust and first arouse the mind of the Way (from the third roll of the Sutra of Wise and Foolish).

source_sentence: 多福王事梵志增福太子奉佛兩師角術九昔有國王。
translation: King Tāfuku served Brahmā, Prince Zengfu, and the two masters of the Buddha's angular arts.9 Once there was a king of a country.
His name was Tāfuku.
The prince's name was Zonfuku.
The king served six masters.
His son served the Buddha.
There were no ascetics in the world.
There was only one white man who took his place as his mentor.
Five hundred non-Buddhists were jealous of his reputation and virtue.
They said to the king.
'The state and the two orders are not the same in mind.
'May I ask the Buddha and his teacher to each display marvelous qualities?'
I'll contract with someone who's not as good as that to be my slave.
The king then allowed them to do so.
The non-Buddhist and the teacher made a pact on the next day.
The king then asked each to test his skills.
The priest who was good at shooting then went into the mountains.
Five hundred men each shot at a huge deer.
They all shot through the left eye and took the horned tricks.
The good man entered the mountain to concentrate his thoughts on the Buddha.
He asked for authority and support to help him realize the great way.
A five-colored deer emerged from the ground in a large group.
They joyfully returned with them.
The non-Buddhists knew about it.
They waited for the good man to leave.
They went to his wife and told her.
"Your husband left home to become an ascetic.
Why don't you just sit on this deer?
That would destroy your family's religious teachings.
The woman was angered by what she heard and begged him for the deer.
When he returned, the good man didn't see the deer.
He asked where it was.
The woman said.
"This inauspicious object has now been lost.
The man was very sad.
He went back up into the mountains and repented wholeheartedly.

source_sentence: 即有明月神珠忽從地出。
translation: Then a bright-moon sacred pearl suddenly emerged from the ground.
She then took this pearl and checked on the travels of the priest.
He went to his door to show off this rare object.
The priest's wife said.

source_sentence: 吾家亦有異物可以相比。
translation: "My family also has something special to compare with that.
She then produced a five-colored deer.
The good man then said.
'The king told me to bring this deer.
Now, if you steal it, your crime won't be fathomed.
The woman quickly returned it.
On the day of the trial, the priests each sent the deer.

source_sentence: 梵志各送鹿皆傷左眼既穢且臭。
translation: Each of the priests who brought the deer was wounded in the left eye, and it was filthy and smelled bad.
The king was very sorry for them.

source_sentence: 賢者來奉奏神鹿齎明月神珠入王殿上。
translation: The good man came to present the sacred deer with the moon-shining sacred pearl and entered the king's hall.

source_sentence: 二物飛騰俱戲星流電耀。
translation: The two things soared up and played with stars and lightning.
The palace was filled with people who praised and marveled at them.
Five hundred people from the Brāhmaṇa school were there.
They knew they weren't as skilled as the others.
They were then enslaved and made into slaves.
Their wives were made into maidservants.

source_sentence: 賢者導示經教以為弟子(出雜譬喻經第三卷)。
translation: That good man guided them through the sūtras and taught them to be his disciples (from Book 3 of the Zaomiao jing).
